titlestmt.author: Processed by the Music Division of the Library of Congress

seriesstmt.titleproper: Guides to Special Collections in the Music Division of the Library of Congress

profiledesc.creation: Finding aid encoded by Library of Congress Music Division, 2010

change.item: Editorial revisions made to this finding aid by Nancy Seeger in March 2010.

did.head: Collection Summary
did.abstract: Dorothea Dix Lawrence was a successful opera singer in the 1930s and 1940s who later became a recitalist and folklorist. The materials in the collection include correspondence, photographs, clippings and other items that document her career as a singer and interpreter of American folk music. In addition, the collection includes her articles on American folklore that were published in various journals and two copies of her famous Folklore Music Map of the United States. The collection also includes piano-vocal opera scores and a large number of American folk songs.

note.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the Library's online catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically therein.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: Gift; Morgan Lawrence, the son of Dorothea Dix Lawrence; 1980.

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: The Dorothea Dix Lawrence Collection was processed by Jonathan Kulp in August 1993. It was coded for EAD by George Kipper in 2010.

separatedmaterial.head: Transfers
separatedmaterial.p: A taped interview with Morgan Lawrence, the son of Dorothea Dix Lawrence, was conducted on July 1, 1980, by Jon Newson, assistant chief of the Library of Congress Music Division. The tape had been sealed until July 1, 2005. It was transferred to the Library of Congress Motion Picture, Broadcasting and Recorded Sound Division and is now accessible to the public.

userestrict.head: Copyright Status
userestrict.p: The status of copyright on the materials of the Dorothea Dix Lawrence Collection is governed by the Copyright Law of the United States (Title 17, U.S.C.).

accessrestrict.head: Access and Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: The Dorothea Dix Lawrence Collection is open to research. Researchers are advised to contact the Performing Arts Reading Room prior to visiting. Many collections are stored off-site and advance notice is needed to retrieve these items for research use.
Certain restrictions to use or copying of materials may apply.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: container number, Dorothea Dix Lawrence Collection, Music Division, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

chronitem.event: Made opera debuts: Montreal, Quebec City, Canada

eventgrp.event: Appeared as Aida with Philadelphia Opera Company, San Carlo Opera Company
Made concert debuts: Studebaker Theatre, Chicago; Jordan Hall, Boston
Produced, directed and performed in weekly radio show Twilight Hour, Trenton, New Jersey
Appeared in the opening concert of the New York World's Fair
Created Primer of American Music for WPEN Philadelphia (27 weekly broadcasts) sponsored by the Board of Education, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania
Published Folklore Music Map of the United States
Produced, directed and starred in Folklore Musicana, an 8-week series on radio station WNYC, New York City

chronitem.event: Collaborated with Gloria Swanson in the television production Design for Living on WPIX-TV, New York City
Published Folklore Songs of the United States (collaboration with Walter Rosemont)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Dorothea Dix Lawrence Collection consists of the correspondence, photographs, clippings, and writings of this noted operatic singer, recitalist, lecturer, and folklorist. The collection also includes piano-vocal opera scores and a large number of American folk songs.

arrangement.head: Organization of the Dorothea Dix Lawrence Collection
arrangement.p: The Dorothea Dix Lawrence Collection is organized into two series:

scopecontent.p: Contains biographical summaries, correspondence, writings, a radio script, clippings, photographs, an award certificate, and Folklore Music Map of the United States (oversize concert poster).

arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by type of material, and chronologically therein.

scopecontent.p: Contains piano-vocal opera scores and other operatic vocal collections, various art songs and American folk songs.

arrangement.p: Arranged by type of music, and alphabetically by composer therein.
